awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Using Salinity Variance to Link Estuarine Mixing and Exchange Flow
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims at advancing our understanding of the physical processes operating in estuaries using the variance of salinity. Salinity is one of the most important quantities defining an estuary and its variance in the horizontal variance provides the driving force for the gravitational circulation.  Vertical variance of salinity quantifies stratification, which strongly affects and is affected by the shear, turbulence and mixing. The salinity variance balance equation has been effectively exploited in the turbulence community to quantify mixing, but it has received surprisingly little attention in context with estuarine dynamics, despite its fundamental importance. This project will analyze the salinity variance balance in a variety of estuaries using realistic and idealized numerical models. The insights gained from the analysis will provide a more systematic understanding of estuarine dynamics, using a common framework to compare rates and mechanisms across the estuarine parameter space. The analysis approach will also have application to exchange flows and mixing in the coastal and global ocean. This project will also support a graduate student at each of the two institutions and contribute to their training. The PIs also plan to teach a 5-week summer class for graduate students entitled "Estuarine Dynamics: Observations and Realistic Models." The class will involve 12-15 graduate students interested in estuarine processes. The students will gain hands-on field experience, and they will also apply and analyze realistic models, thereby developing a sense of the challenge and synergy that comes from bringing together observations and models. 

This project will develop the mathematical framework of the salinity variance to quantify the integral relationships between exchange flow and mixing, and then apply those relationships to diverse estuarine settings. In addition to these integral relationships, the analysis will examine the local exchange between horizontal and vertical variance via straining, and determine the consequences for temporal and spatial variations of stratification and mixing. Here "mixing" is defined as the irreversible loss of salinity variance by turbulent and molecular processes. The analysis will address these fundamental questions: Is exchange flow controlled by mixing, or vice versa? How do mixing and exchange flow respond to variations in tidal amplitude in different estuarine regimes? How does estuarine geometry affect mixing and exchange flow? How does straining by estuarine and tidal shear vary in different regimes, and how does straining modulate the exchange between horizontal and vertical variance and thereby enhance or suppress mixing? The answers to these questions will lead to a predictive framework for the variability of estuarine mixing and exchange flow in relation to the estuarine geometry and the dominant forcing parameters; river discharge and tides.

por.por_cntn:
Estuaries play a key role in the global hydrological cycle?they are the locations where fresh water from continental run-off is converted back into seawater, the latter which comprises more than 97% of the earth?s water volume.  That conversion, which is the mixing of fresh and salt water in estuaries, is one of the most important aspects of the physical science of estuaries, because mixing is a key factor in determining the motion of water within the estuary and the exchange of material such as oxygen, nutrients and pollutants within the estuary and across its boundaries with the adjoining terrestrial environment, seabed, atmosphere and coastal ocean. 

This project directly addressed the mixing between fresh and salt water by calculating the salinity variance?i.e., the variability of salt content within the estuarine volume, and examining the factors that influence that variability.  The input of fresh water from land and seawater from the ocean are the sources of salinity variance, and mixing is process that destroys variance by homogenizing the water within the estuary, just like an egg beater homogenizes the yolk and albumin of an egg on the way to becoming scrambled eggs. 

One of the outcomes of this study was to demonstrate that over long timescales relative to the tides and freshwater inflow, the destruction of salinity variance, i.e., mixing, can be directly related to the ?exchange flow?, the net inflow and outflow of estuarine water.  The exchange flow has long been recognized to be the most important mechanism for circulating and renewing the water in large estuaries?tidal currents being more important in small estuaries.  Our project provided a formal analysis of the linkage between the exchange flow and mixing. 

Another important outcome of this study was to determine the conditions favorable for mixing and the mechanisms that produce those conditions.  Not surprisingly, mixing is enhanced in regions of intensified turbulence.  But mixing also requires the presence of strong salinity gradients (changes in salinity over short distances, particularly in the vertical direction).  So, it is the co-occurrence of strong vertical salinity gradients with strong turbulence that provide the most intense mixing. 

While this may seem intuitively obvious, the problem is complicated by the fact that strong turbulence tends to destroy vertical gradients?a process that has long been noted in estuaries and which leads to variations in stratification (i.e., vertical salinity gradient) induced by variations in the intensity of tidal currents (for example the 2-week ?spring-neap? cycle of tidal amplitude).  So, the intensification of mixing occurs in the special circumstances when there is both strong stratification and strong mixing.

This study revealed that circumstances that lead to this unlikely combination of strong gradients and strong mixing are salinity fronts.  Just like fronts in the atmosphere that cause stormy weather, salinity fronts are regions of intensified horizontal salinity gradient, usually accompanied by strong vertical shear in the velocity (i.e., the strength of the current changes strongly with depth).  This combination of strong horizontal salinity gradient and strong vertical shear results in ?straining? of the salinity distribution, converting the horizontal gradient into vertical gradient.  As long as this frontal condition persists, salinity stratification can be continually generated, even in the presence of strong vertical mixing.  Such frontal regions can be thought of as the ?mixing factories? of estuaries, where fresh water is converted into salt water. 

Why is this important?  As we noted at the beginning of this report, the mixing in estuaries is directly related to the exchange, which in turn is directly related to the distribution of properties and water quality.  The more vigorous the mixing, the more rapid the exchange, and in most cases the better the water quality.  And just as in all scientific investigations, the better the processes are understood, the more accurate predictions we can make about how intentional and unintentional changes in the structure and forcing conditions of natural environments may affect the characteristics of those environments that we value.
